citations.narrative:
The concrete shelter for the 10-year old male lion and the same type of shelter for a liger had little bedding for the cold
weather. At the start of the inspection, the lion was hunched up inside the shelter, intermittently raising his paws off the
floor and groaning. The floor of the shelter had a thin layer of frozen wet straw along some picked-clean bones. The
outdoor temperature at the time of the inspection was 10 degrees F. There as about 12 inches of snow on the ground
inside the enclosure in front of the shelter. When climatic condition present a threat to the animal's health or well-being,
appropriate measures must be taken to alleviate the impact of those conditions. For severe cold and blizzard conditions,
this could be in the form of deep, dry bedding added to the shelter or other form of insulating material to help keep the
animal warm. Ensure that the lion and liger are appropriately bedded and kept warm when climatic conditions pose a
threat to the animal's health.
***Corrected by providing straw bedding to the shelters during inspection. Maintain compliance starting 1/18/24.

The male lion's water was observed to be frozen. The representative said that the lion doesn't like to walk in the snow and
so his water hasn't been refreshed for 2 days since he doesn't walk out to his water dish when there is snow on the
ground. Not providing fresh drinking water to the lion for 2 days does not ensure its well being. The facility representative
had an employee find a dish that would fit closer to the shelter opening and provided fresh drinking water prior to the exit
interview.
***Ensure that the lion and each animal is provided potable water as often as necessary for the health and comfort of the
animal.
Maintain correct from 1/18/24 going forward.
This inspection was conducted with a facility representative and exit interview was conducted with the licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
SCOTT WELCH, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.131(e)  Direct
   
Handling of animals. 
The concrete shelter for the 10-year old male lion and the same type of shelter for a liger had little bedding for the cold 
weather. At the start of the inspection, the lion was hunched up inside the shelter, intermittently raising his paws off the 
floor and groaning. The floor of the shelter had a thin layer of frozen wet straw along some picked-clean bones. The 
outdoor temperature at the time of the inspection was 10 degrees F. There as about 12 inches of snow on the ground 
inside the enclosure in front of the shelter. When climatic condition present a threat to the animal's health or well-being, 
appropriate measures must be taken to alleviate the impact of those conditions. For severe cold and blizzard conditions, 
this could be in the form of deep, dry bedding added to the shelter or other form of insulating material to help keep the 
animal warm. Ensure that the lion and liger are appropriately bedded and kept warm when climatic conditions pose a 
threat to the animal's health.  
 
***Corrected by providing straw bedding to the shelters during inspection. Maintain compliance starting 1/18/24. 
3.130  Direct
   
Watering. 
The male lion's water was observed to be frozen. The representative said that the lion doesn't like to walk in the snow and 
so his water hasn't been refreshed for 2 days since he doesn't walk out to his water dish when there is snow on the 
ground. Not providing fresh drinking water to the lion for 2 days does not ensure its well being. The facility representative 
had an employee find a dish that would fit closer to the shelter opening and provided fresh drinking water prior to the exit 
interview.  
 
***Ensure that the lion and each animal is provided potable water as often as necessary for the health and comfort of the 
animal. 
 
Maintain correct from 1/18/24 going forward. 
 
This inspection was conducted with a facility representative and exit interview was conducted with the licensee.

Additional Inspectors: 
SCOTT WELCH, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
